Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
Project Number: 51254-001  
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
December 2017 
 
 
Almaty–Bishkek Economic Corridor Support
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB's Public Communications 
Policy 2011.
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ABEC  –  Almaty–Bishkek Economic Corridor 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  CAREC  –  Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation Program 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
Vice-President  Wencai Zhang, Operations 1 
Director General  Sean O’Sullivan, Central and West Asia Department (CWRD) 
Director  Safdar Parvez, Regional Cooperation and Operations Coordination 
Division, CWRD

ThisdocumentmustonlybegeneratedineOps. 13072017100204433415 Generated Date: 08-Jan-2018 9:36:09 AM  Page 2 of 2

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The regional knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will support implementation 
of a pilot cross-border economic corridor around Almaty and Bishkek under the Central Asia 
Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) program. The Almaty–Bishkek Economic Corridor 
(ABEC) aims to further integrate the relatively dense economic area in Central Asia and create 
one  economic  space  without  barriers,  following  a  multisector  approach.  ABEC  will  allow 
businesses  to  specialize  more,  operate  at  a  larger  scale,  and  achieve  greater  economic 
diversification and competitiveness with the purpose of exporting goods and services outside the 
region.  
 
2.  ABEC enjoys strong political support from the governments of Kazakhstan and the Kyrgyz 
Republic. In 2017, the two governments created the ABEC subcommittee—chaired by the vice-
ministers of economy—under the Kazakhstan–Kyrgyz Republic Intergovernmental Council, which 
is headed by both countries’ prime ministers.  
 
3.  This TA builds on analytical and conceptual work completed under Technical Assistance 
for Assisting the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation Institute Knowledge Program 
(Phase 1), which facilitated the preparation of ABEC development reports covering agricultural 
value  chains,  tourism,  urban  development,  education,  health,  disaster  risk  management, 
information and communication technology applications, and connectivity.1 A joint working group 
of government and private sector representatives performed this work with support from Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) consultants. A steering committee approved an investment framework 
for ABEC in September 2016 to mark the end of the analytical phase and the start of the 
implementation phase.2  
 
4.  The TA will identify investment projects for ADB, the governments, the private sector, and 
other development partners through the platform of the corridor.3 The TA will also actively promote 
private sector investments in the corridor, support the further institutionalization of ABEC, and 
assist the ABEC subcommittee in identifying, prioritizing, and sequencing ABEC projects and 
reform initiatives. 
 
I.  ISSUES 
5.  ABEC is a pilot cross-border economic corridor and a flagship of regional integration under 
the CAREC program. Despite their proximity, the travel time between Almaty and Bishkek often 
takes more than four hours because of the cumbersome border crossing. Markets for services 
and agricultural products are separated, which limits their scale, specialization, and hence curbs 
the region’s potential for exports. ABEC will address these bottlenecks through setting up cross-
border agricultural value chains, integrating tourism markets, improving coordination in social 
sectors, and shortening travel times for commuters. ABEC interventions are expected to boost 
agricultural  productivity,  certification  and  exports,  create  new  income  opportunities  through 
attracting international tourists, allow for specialized health services and vocational education, 
and further improve the export competitiveness of Almaty, Bishkek, and the surrounding regions.  
 
                                                
1  ADB. 2012. Technical Assistance for Assisting the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation Institute Knowledge 
Program (Phase 1). Manila (TA 8259-REG). 
2  ADB. 2016. Growing Together—Almaty–Bishkek Corridor Initiative Investment Framework. Manila 
3  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 11 September 2017.

2 
 
6.  The governments of Kazakhstan and the Kyrgyz Republic, primarily represented by their 
respective ministries of economy, the city administrations of Almaty and Bishkek, and the regional 
governments of Almaty, Zhambyl, Chui, and Issyk-Kul, have together with ADB developed the 
concept for creating an economic corridor through investment projects, regulatory reforms, and 
knowledge  exchange.4 This  work  has  drawn  on  the  international  experience  of  the  most 
successful economic corridors. 
 
7.  The two governments envision the corridor as an integrated economic space between the 
cities of Almaty and Bishkek and their surroundings to foster trade, enhance free movement of 
labor and capital, and modernize infrastructure. The cross-border corridor will promote greater 
diversification and competitiveness, allowing businesses to specialize more, operate at a larger 
scale, and experience agglomeration benefits. The two cities and four regions can achieve far 
more together than either can achieve alone. 
 
8.  The ABEC subcommittee, which consists of senior government officials from different 
ministries and senior professionals, will oversee the implementation and further development of 
the corridor with the support of this TA. The private sector will drive most investments to the 
corridor. Transformative public investments, public–private partnerships, the integrated market, 
skilled human capital, and high-quality infrastructure and services will attract these investments. 
These investments will require reforms to improve public policy and the regulatory environment,5 
as well as project preparatory analytical work to showcase the feasibility of the projects and their 
regional impacts. Further to that, this TA will support cooperation between the two governments 
to develop a common regulatory environment that is consistent with agreements under the 
Eurasian Economic Union.   
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: strengthened regional economic cooperation 
in the CAREC region.6 The TA will have the following outcome: ABEC is an integrated economic 
space and serves as a pilot economic corridor under the CAREC program.7 The outcome will lead 
to additional benefits, including (i) forging a coordinated approach to developing agriculture and 
services in the corridor and making both cities more attractive targets for skilled labor and 
investments, (ii) maximizing regional benefits from investment projects and reforms across 
sectors, (iii) increasing the scale and specialization of products and services, and (iv) enhancing 
export competitiveness. Selected projects will be environmentally sustainable. 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities  
10.  Output 1: Projects and reforms with regional impacts identified and prepared in the 
Almaty–Bishkek Economic Corridor. The TA will identify and prepare ABEC projects for 
implementation  during  2018–2020.  Benefits  will  align  with  national  priorities  and  maximize 
                                                
4  The TA is relevant to ADB’s Operational Plan for Regional Cooperation and Integration—particularly operational 
direction 1 ("strengthening connectivity between economies") and operational direction 2 ("raising competitiveness 
in connected markets"). ADB. 2016. Operational plan for regional cooperation and integration, 2016–2020: Promoting 
connectivity, competitiveness, regional public goods, and collective action for Asia and the Pacific. Manila. 
5  This TA benefits from the work under ADB. 2014. Supporting Industrial Park Development in Central Asia Regional 
Economic Cooperation Region. Manila (TA 8782-REG). 
6  ADB. 2012. CAREC 2020: A Strategic Framework for the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation Program 
2011–2020. Manila. 
7  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

3 
 
regional development impacts and spillovers. The TA will support the development of a 3-year 
rolling pipeline of regional projects and policy reforms under ABEC. They will be prioritized based 
on (i) value for money, (ii) potential to spin off exports of services or products, (iii) bankability and 
potential to attract private investments, and (iv) positive externalities across sectors. The projects 
will support national and regional strategies and will be aligned with international commitments. 
A  pool  of  international  and  national  experts  will  help  identify  and  prepare  projects. 
Representatives from the two governments have identified a set of initial projects for advanced 
implementation in agriculture and tourism that will showcase the advantages of economic and 
logistical integration made possible by the corridor approach. Work has already begun on first 
ADB ABEC agribusiness project, which will establish cross-border value chains for food products.8 
Tourism facilitation projects are also being conceptualized. 
 
11.  Output 2: Implementation plans are finalized. For the corridor to generate shared 
benefits in both countries and become replicable, the 3-year rolling project pipeline will be outlined 
in annual implementation plans. The implementation plans will help prioritize and sequence 
investment projects and integrate existing public, private, and development partner projects. The 
implementation plans will outline the necessary reforms and regulatory adjustments to maximize 
value for money and attract private investments. Such adjustments will require high-level political 
commitment and consensus among the stakeholders. 
 
12.  Output 3: Almaty–Bishkek Economic Corridor is institutionalized. The TA will support 
work of the ABEC subcommittee, support secretariat functions for the ABEC subcommittee 
meetings, and facilitate the work of sector working groups. This will require maintaining close 
coordination between the countries and across different levels of government. The TA will also 
support outreach activities of the corridor to attract public and private investments. The TA will 
also suggest different ways to further institutionalize the corridor, including through generated 
revenues from services for the design and implementation of projects. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,800,000, of which $1,000,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-6), and $750,000 will be financed on 
a grant basis by the Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund.9 The in-kind contributions of the 
governments are estimated to amount to $50,000. The key expenditure items, to be financed on 
parallel basis, are listed in Appendix 2. 
 
14.  The governments of Kazakhstan and the Kyrgyz Republic will provide counterpart support 
in the form of counterpart staff, office, office supplies, all required materials, information, data, 
and other in-kind contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  ADB will administer the TA.10 In particular, the Central and West Asia Department will 
select, supervise, and evaluate consultants; procure goods and services; organize workshops; 
and provide staff to act as resource persons in meetings and workshops. 
 
 
                                                
8     ADB. 2017. Country Operations Business Plan: Kazakhstan, 2018–2020. Manila. 
9   Established by ADB. Financing partner: the Government of Japan. 
10  ADB will obtain a no-objection in writing from the governments of the Republic of Kazakhstan and the Kyrgyz 
Republic prior to conducting or financing any TA activity in the territory of said countries.

16.  Consulting services. The TA will require the services of international and national 
experts. A consulting firm and individual consultants will be recruited in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time), and the associated 
project administration instructions and/or TA staff instructions as outlined in the table. The TA will 
finance approximately 44 person-months of international consulting and 74 person-months of 
national consulting services using both input-based contracts and, where appropriate, output-
based or lumpsum contracts.11 A pool of international and national consultants will support the 
preparation of investment projects and related policy reforms to accelerate the implementation of 
the ABEC.12 The terms of reference for the consultants will be finalized in consultation with the 
ABEC subcommittee once specific ABEC projects and reform initiatives have been agreed upon, 
and  depending  on  the  recruitment  of  a  firm  or  individual  consultants,  whichever  is  more 
appropriate for the selected ABEC initiatives. The consulting firms will be selected using the 
quality and cost-based selection method with a quality–cost ratio of 90:10. 
 
17.  ADB’s procurement. All TA financed goods and services will be procured in accordance 
with ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and the associated PAIs/TA 
                                                
11  ADB. 2014. Midterm Review of Strategy 2020 Action Plan. Manila. 
12  Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

5 
 
Staff Instructions. The TA equipment budget includes computers and small office equipment. 
Assets, including fixed assets, will be turned over to the governments or disposed after TA 
completion in line with ADB rules and regulations, specifically Administrative Order No. 4.02. 
Disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with ADB's Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).  
 
 
III.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision  of  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $1,750,000  (aggregated 
amount) on a grant basis for the Almaty–Bishkek Economic Corridor Support, and hereby reports 
this action to the Board.

Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  Projects and reforms with regional impacts identified and prepared in the Almaty–Bishkek 
Economic Corridor 
1.1 Mobilize consultants (November 2017–December 2019). 
1.2 Identify projects in priority agriculture and tourism sectors, other ABEC sectors (November 2017–
December 2019). 
1.3 Assess projects based on distribution of costs and benefits between the countries, regions, and cities 
(October 2017–March 2020). 
1.4 Attract private investments through dialogue with the private sector, including outreach activities such 
as investment forums; through regulatory reforms that increase the viability of projects; and through 
integrated financing approaches such as public–private partnerships (February 2018–March 2020). 
2.  Implementation plans are finalized 
2.1 Mobilize consultants (January 2018–December 2019).  
2.2 Conceptualize approaches to assess public and private investment projects in terms of distribution of 
costs and benefits (February 2018–February 2019). 
2.3 Integrate sector work to show agglomeration benefits (February 2018–February 2019). 
3.    Almaty–Bishkek Economic Corridor is institutionalized  
3.1 Mobilize consultants (November 2017–December 2019). 
3.2 Lend the ABEC subcommittee administrative support and expertise through a pool of sector experts 
(November 2017–March 2020). 
3.3 Develop a branding concept for the corridor to facilitate private investments (January 2018–
September 2019). 
3.4 Develop a set of standards and regulatory reforms to increase the competitiveness of the corridor 
(September 2018–March 2020).  
Inputs 
ADB:  $1,000,000  
Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund: $750,000 
Note: The governments of Kazakhstan and the Kyrgyz Republic will provide counterpart support in the 
form of counterpart staff, office, office supplies, all required materials, information, data, and other in-kind 
contributions. 
Assumptions for Partner Financing 
Additional cofinancing will be considered during implementation. 
ABEC = Almaty–Bishkek Economic Corridor, ADB = Asian Development Bank, CAREC = Central Asia Regional 
Economic Cooperation Program, TA = technical assistance.

development. 
Source: Asian Development Bank.

Bank and the Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund are presented in the table above. The governments of 
Kazakhstan and the Kyrgyz Republic will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office and housing 
accommodation, office supplies, secretarial assistance, domestic transportation, and other in-kind contributions. The 
key expenditure items will be financed on a parallel basis. The value of government contribution is estimated to account 
for 2.8% of the total TA cost.

costs will remain below $50,000.
